title: Add a null-safe trim(String) method to Strings
Add a null-safe hashCode(Object) helper method to Objects
Objects.equalAny method
Stop watch time elapsed not specific.
Improvement request: Cache.put(k, v) should return previous cache value
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=843) created by **morten.hattesen** on 2011-12-26 at 10:40 PM_

---

Guava API version: 11

The current signature of the Cache.put method does not allow to atomically determine if the call to the put method caused a change to the cache, as the return type is void.

Would it not be more appropriate to let the Cache.put(K key, V value) return the previous value, mimicking the Map.put() operation, i.e.

```
V put(K key, V value)
```

I assume the Cache.put method is placed in the Cache API merely as a convenience method for...

```
Cache.asMap().put(K key, V value)
```

... which does indeed return the previously cached value (atomically)

If this change is not desired, I suggest the JavaDoc is extended to cover the more elaborate put operation via the Map view.

title: new Stopwatch() throws exception java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError on Ubuntu
body: _[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=842) created by **tdziurko** on 2011-12-26 at 01:14 PM_ --- What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Stopwatch stopwatch = new Stopwatch(); What is the expected output? What do you see instead? It should create new instance of Stopwatch. What I get is: java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError: Found interface com.google.common.base.Ticker, but class was expected     at com.google.common.base.Stopwatch.<init>(Stopwatch.java:84) What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Guava 10.0.1, Ubuntu 10, Java 1.6.0_26 Please provide any additional information below.

title: CacheBuilder class JavaDoc ambiguity concerning reclaim of cache entries

labels.name: type=documentation
labels.description: Documentation that is other than for an API

body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=841) created by **morten.hattesen** on 2011-12-26 at 11:41 AM_

---

This issue relates to the class level JavaDoc for CacheBuilder (r11) and similar wording in CacheBuilder (r10.1).

CacheBuilder https://google.github.io/guava/releases/v11.0/apidocs/com/google/common/cache/CacheBuilder.html

JavaDoc Quote: "If weakKeys, weakValues, or softValues are requested, it is possible for a key or value present in the cache to be reclaimed by the garbage collector. Reclaimed entries may be removed from the cache on each cache modification, on occasional cache accesses, or on calls to Cache.cleanUp()."

It is not self-explanatory what the link between a garbage collected (reclaimed) "key or value" and the removal of the associated cache entry is.

I guess the main cause of ambiguity is the statement "Reclaimed entries may...", whereas the preceding sentence does not mention "entries" at all, but covers reclaiming "keys or value".

As I understand it, once a (soft or weak) cache key or value has been reclaimed by the garbage collector, the associated cache entry is effectively invalidated, and subject to removal.

Soft- and weak references are not the most widely understood Java language features, so any features relying on them need to be concisely documented to avoid client programmers dropping the use of cache expiry, or relying on trial-by-error, which is even further complicated by the non-determinism of the JVM garbage collector.

I therefore propose that the cache entry reclaim process is better documented, w.r.t. soft- and weak references in the reference documentation (JavaDoc).

title: Futures.immediateFailedFuture cannot hold an Error
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=840) created by **brianfromoregon** on 2011-12-26 at 01:24 AM_

---

I can see this choice was intentional, but it's causing me grief because in my case if an Error is thrown down the call stack it will be silently ignored. I need to channel it through to another thread which will later throw it. Why don't you allow holding Errors, because _most_ of the time it's the wrong thing to do?

Guava 11.0 release breaks older google-collections users.
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=836) created by **vdiet...@spanning.com** on 2011-12-23 at 06:33 PM_

---

While attempting to remove the google-collections dependency in my gdata 1.46.0 application, I ran into an incompatibility with the latest guava release.

Using guava 11.0, I get the following exception stack trace when attempting to instantiate any com.google.gdata.client.Service-derived subclass (my particular usage was a com.google.gdata.client.docs.DocsService):

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.google.common.collect.ImmutableSet.of([Ljava/lang/Object;)Lcom/google/common/collect/ImmutableSet;
    at com.google.gdata.wireformats.AltFormat$Builder.setAcceptableTypes(AltFormat.java:399)
    at com.google.gdata.wireformats.AltFormat$Builder.setAcceptableXmlTypes(AltFormat.java:387)
    at com.google.gdata.wireformats.AltFormat.<clinit>(AltFormat.java:49)
    at com.google.gdata.client.Service.<clinit>(Service.java:558)
...

Switching back to guava 10.0.1 solves the runtime issue for me for now, but if guava is supposed to be a drop-in replacement for the deprecated google-collections I thought it worth a note.

title: allow forced cache refresh
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=835) created by **wwadge** on 2011-12-23 at 05:34 PM_

---

Usually periodically calling LoadingCache.cleanup() is sufficient to trigger checks to eliminate all expired entries (access/write). However as of version 12 it does not check entries that are due for a refresh via the refreshOnWrite setting.

There's a little more discussion available here: http://groups.google.com/group/guava-discuss/t/c0352a941f48885d

title: Could you add helper methods for compareTo isBefore and isAfter or similar?
Feature Request: Function for resolving Futures
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=833) created by **raymond.rishty** on 2011-12-22 at 12:35 PM_

---

Currently Guava has a method Futures.allAsList, which takes a bunch of Futures and returns a Future of a List. This works great.

However, I'd wonder if the concept could be expanded to allow greater flexibility by giving a simple Function<ListenableFuture<T>, T> that just calls .get() on the future. This would allow one to not only resolve the whole list, but also to use other data structures.

I ran into the "need" for this in a situation where I had a Map of futures with names; the key was the name, and the value was the future. I could iterate over the entries, resolve each future, and put the value in a new map, or I could run a Maps.transformEntries over it.

Can you make the abstract collection classes (e.g., AbstractMultimap) public?

Others could then subclass them to create their own collections, such MultisetMultimap, which aren't in Guava.

title: Multiple hash iterations

Enhancement - Internal Logging Facade (decouple from java.util.logging)
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=829) created by **jmsignup** on 2011-12-18 at 09:27 PM_

---

Guava is an excellent library, and it prudently uses logging in places like Closeables.closeQuietly(Closeable) when an IOException is caught but not rethrown.

However, it is coupled to the java.util.logging logging implementation.  This makes adapting guava logging to existing projects difficult, if those projects use a different log framework.  Converting to slf4j has been discussed but rejected to limit non-JRE dependencies.  The discussion suggests using slf4j's jul-to-slf4j bridge, but that comes with a 20% performance reduction, even with the latest logback implementation.  As the jul-to-slf4j bridge documentation notes, the java.util.logging implementation is more difficult to work around because it is a part of the java namespace, which has certain restrictions on it.

Instead, enhance guava to intoduce an internal logging facade.  This is in some ways similar to slf4j but without bringing in any new dependencies.  By using an internal logging facade, guava because decoupled from java.util.logging, allowing pluggable logging implementations.  

I suggest using a model similar to Netty's internal logging pattern, which exists for this very purpose.  By having a logger and logger factory internal interface, you allow a simple extension to the library for using whatever logging implementation the user wants.  By default, you can enable a java.util.logging implemetation (I suggest calling it something like JulLoggerFactory instead of Netty's JdkLoggerFactory, but that's a minor note).  There are plenty of good logger interfaces available to model after.  As I see it, you mainly need isXxxxLevelEnabled() and log.xxxx(String, Throwable) for the decided upon logging priority levels (like in log4j's Logger).

One other recommendation to Netty's implementation.  I would prefer configuring the logger factory from a static call and also by specifying a class name in a system property.  A system property ensures configurability at startup and is a pattern used throughout the JRE APIs, allowing for greater flexibility and adaptability to existing projects.

Minimizing non-JRE dependencies is a great goal for a common library like Guava but allow for plugging in other logging implementations for easier acceptance into more projects.

References:
- Discussion to have Guava use slf4j: http://groups.google.com/group/guava-discuss/browse_thread/thread/56ab7f9ac9d922dd
- java.util.logging to slf4j bridge: http://www.slf4j.org/legacy.html#jul-to-slf4j
- Netty's internal logging javadoc: http://docs.jboss.org/netty/3.1/api/org/jboss/netty/logging/package-summary.html

It seems that because all fields in AbstractMultimap are transient, the GWT exposure computer decides that the the map values are not exposed, and omits the value type from the serialization policy.

Please see the attached file. I've modified the GWT demo project to show this error.

title: Provide BitUnit and ByteUnit (like java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit)
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=827) created by **fabian.barney** on 2011-12-15 at 06:29 PM_

---

It is very much the same like TimeUnit but for Bits and Bytes.

Both are enums and can be used for:
- converting (Bits<->Bytes) (i.e. BitUnit.KBIT.toKiB(16000))
- converting (betwenn different prefixes) (i.e. ByteUnit.GB.toMB(1))
- as a param type for methods etc. (i.e. setContentLength(int value, ByteUnit unit))

Enums are using terminology for prefixes from IEC 80000-13. (i.e. Kilo is 10^3 and Kibi is 2^10)

I've already implemented it: https://github.com/fabian-barney/Utils/tree/master/utils/src/com/barney4j/utils

It is under Apache License 2 and I would be happy to see it in guava.

There is a stackoverflow question about this:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8495881/is-there-a-java-enum-for-filesize-units-thats-equivalent-to-java-util-concurren

title: Document AbstractScheduledService concurrency policy
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=826) created by **tpeierls** on 2011-12-15 at 04:11 PM_

---

The use of unguarded fields in the example in the class comment of AbstractScheduledService strongly suggests that runOneIteration will never be executed by more than one thread concurrently, and that there are happens-before edges between consecutive calls to runOneIteration. 

I can't find a guarantee of this in the docs, however.

title: Spelling error in example in AbstractScheduledService class comment
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=825) created by **tpeierls** on 2011-12-15 at 04:06 PM_

---

The class comment for AbstractScheduledService in 11.0-rc1 has an example that defines a protected method schedule() returning a Schedule, but the actual API defines protected method scheduler() returning a Scheduler.

In addition, the example uses newFixedRateSchedule instead of newFixedRateScheduler.

title: Add Strings.replaceFirst/Last(String, CharSequence, CharSequence)
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=824) created by **ogregoire** on 2011-12-15 at 12:55 PM_

---

The methods replaceAll(String regex, String replacement) and split(String regex [, ]) have their "fix".

Please consider also "fixing" replaceFirst(String regex, String replacement) by creating a method Strings.replaceFirst(String, CharSequence, CharSequence) that would not use regexes to find a String to modify.

On the same level, if Strings.replaceFirst is accepted, consider including replaceLast.

I just can't find a one-liner to do that. (It's possible with Splitter and Joiner for replaceFirst, but not for replaceLast.)

title: Provide immutable MediaType class
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=823) created by **j...@nwsnet.de** on 2011-12-14 at 02:08 PM_

---

While the Java Mail API provides a content type class, it still has some drawbacks. Some are that it's not immutable (think constants) and it lacks a (static) constructor to create one just from primary and sub type as separate arguments without specifying a(n empty) list of parameters.

Also, HTTP uses MIME/content types as well, but those projects might not want to depend on an e-mail-related package.

My personal requirements:
- immutability
- Allow explicit addressing of the charset both on construction and as a getter (not just having to find it by key in the list of parameters).
- Provide matching of the primary type, the sub type, parameters, and combinations of all of those (say, primary type and sub type and charset).
- Maybe support matchers like "text/*", i.e. a wildcard for the sub type (that case might be sufficient). However, comparison with/without parameters (or just a selection of those) might require some further thinking.
- Handle case (in)sensivity as appropriate. There are different requirements for the parameters of certain MIME types on how to interpret their keys and values regarding that.
- Provide conversion methods from/to `ContentType` (Java Mail API).
- Have a thoughtful implementation of `equals`. I think everything should be compared, including parameters.

) From my own investigation:
- According to RFC 2045, section 5.1, the primary type, subtype, and parameter names must always be matched case insensitive.
- According to RFC 2046, section 4.1.2, the value of the charset parameter (implicit default: US-ASCII) is case insensitive, but the values of other parameters might not be.

I have implemented an immutable content type myself, but so far only included specifically the charset parameter of text types, but no other parameters (e.g. filename; not to confuse with the parameter of the `Content-Disposition: attachment` header).

Also, a builder-style approach might be useful to optionally add parameters as needed before the immutable instance is created.

On a related note, the Guava class that contains HTTP header keys is quite nice. Maybe something similar for common content types would make sense? In that case, the content type class' API should allow for composition of pre-defined primary/sub type combinations (plaintext, HTML, CSV, JSON, octet-stream, PDF, images etc.) with parameters to fit specific needs.

title: Decrease in generated garbage
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=820) created by **frank.pavageau** on 2011-12-12 at 12:11 PM_

---

Predicates$AndPredicate and Predicate$OrPredicate use a for-each loop in their apply method when they could use for (int i = 0, size = components.size(); ...) since the components field contains an ArrayList.

It might seem like a premature optimization, but it's really not. I have a project relying heavily on guava for some pretty intensive computations, and the iterators instanciated by these 2 predicates alone amount to 1.5% of the number of garbage-collected objects and 1% of the size.

title: Provide some default Optional-Values
FluentFunction
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=818) created by **em...@soldal.org** on 2011-12-09 at 08:15 AM_

---

I am finding myself writing increasingly complex functions these days, the introduction of Guava and the use of the Function/Functions methods for accessing data is proving to be very useful. 

The only drawback we're seeing is that the code becomes increasingly difficult to follow, so I want to propose the following class.

If we could add this method to Functions.java:
public static <A,B> FunctionComposer<A,B> composer(Function<A,B> delegate) {
   return new FunctionComposer<A,B>(delegate);
}

we could use the following code to provide a better composition API:
https://gist.github.com/1450697

Thanks,
 Emily

The following is specified in the class-javadoc header 'The collections generated by entries, keys, and values iterate across the keys according to the above key ordering, and for each key they iterate across the values according to the value ordering.'

I suggest it is (mostly) replicated in the method javadoc for values + kes + entries. 

entries-javadoc already contain info regarding ordering, it mostly just misses the word 'sorted'

values-javadoc already contain some info regarding ordering, though nothing on the sort-order.

Regarding the type of the argument, both an iterable as well as varargs would be appropriate depending on the situation and the number of optionals to check.

title: Files.deleteDirectoryContents
Post an event to a specific object in an EventBus
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=808) created by **goo...@sa.me.uk** on 2011-11-30 at 12:19 AM_

---

I'd like to be able to post an event to an object immediately before registering it. Currently the only way to do that is to have a separate temporary event bus that's only used to post events. (There are synchronization requirements for this, but that can be handled externally to the EventBus).

title: WeakEventBus that uses a weak reference to registered objects
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=807) created by **goo...@sa.me.uk** on 2011-11-29 at 10:27 PM_

---

EventBus maintains a strong reference to registered objects, and objects can't easily be wrapped in a WeakReference because that would need to @Subscribe to the same events.

WeakEventBus would use a WeakReference to refer to registered objects and unregister them automatically using a ReferenceQueue.

title: Missing parts in I/O API
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=806) created by **ogregoire** on 2011-11-28 at 08:16 PM_

---

I recently modified all of my reader method to accept InputSupplier as parameter instead of the usual InputStream or the Reader and I started doing the same for my OutputStreams and Writers.

What was my surprise when I saw that no OutputSupplier factory methods exist in Guava except for those in the Files class. It really felt like there is a whole part of the I/O API that is completely missing.

I would be nice to add the following to the API:
- NullWriter;
- Null{OutputStream/Writer} suppliers as factory methods;
- ByteArrayOutputStream/CharArrayWriter suppliers or suppliers that allow writing to a given byte/char array.

I know I can easily make a NullWriter (by making new OutputStreamWriter(new NullOutputStream())), but this is so unnatural since, with java.io, we expect to see the mirror classes when possible.

I had to write all this code today, but I'm quite sure everybody can benefit from it (even if this is now quite old and no one suggested it before).

If accepted, can this still make it for release 11?

title: invalid boolean expression
Add static generic constructor methods to Builder classes
Support for custom annotations and/or HandlerFindingStrategy in EventBus
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=803) created by **gushaa** on 2011-11-24 at 08:10 PM_

---

Since annotations cannot be extended in Java it would be nice to support a way to replace the @Subscribe and @AllowConcurrentEvents annotations with a custom ones. 
If that cannot be done or is not desirable then a way to implement ones own HandlerFindingStrategy would be a nice addition. Right now the finder variable is private final and there is no way to set it from the outside. Also the HandlerFindingStrategy interface is not public.

The reason for doing something like this is to be able to create a facade for EventBuses so that the implementation can be substituted if needed and also so that one can define another interface towards the EventBus behaviour. That is not possible at the moment because of the annotations.

title: Entries from MapMaker.weakValues() are not removed
body: _[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=801) created by **boucher.frederic** on 2011-11-23 at 01:38 PM_ --- What steps will reproduce the problem? Using guava 10.0.0 : - Instantiate a new MapMaker.weakValues().makeMap(); - Put a new value: map.put("KEY1", new Object()); - Launch the garbage collector using System.gc(); "KEY1" is no longer available but the associated entry is never removed from the map. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Except that the entries from a map built using MapMaker.weakValues().makeMap() are removed after the weak value is garbage collected. But the entries are never removed. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? The Entry removal works with guava 9.0.0 but not with 10.0.0

title: MultiMap<K,V> construction factory from Map<V,K>
HashBasedTable GWT-RPC Serialization Exception
body: _[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=791) created by **mishamo** on 2011-11-15 at 11:08 AM_ --- What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Instantiate a HashBasedTable<X,Y,Z> with HashBasedTable.create(); where X, Y and Z are all 'IsSerializable' types. 2. Send the table as part of a GWT-RPC request. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected output is to receive the HashBasedTable<X,Y,Z> on the servlet side. Instead this exception is thrown by GWT: com.google.gwt.user.client.rpc.SerializationException     at Unknown.$fillInStackTrace(StackTraceCreator.java:168)     at Unknown.fillInStackTrace(StackTraceCreator.java:421)     at Unknown.Exception_0(Throwable.java:46)     at Unknown.SerializationException_0(SerializationException.java:27)     at Unknown.$check(SerializerBase.java:137)     at Unknown.$serialize(SerializerBase.java:122)     at Unknown.$writeObject(AbstractSerializationStreamWriter.java:126)     at Unknown.serialize_7(HashBasedTable_CustomFieldSerializer.java:56)     at Unknown.$serialize_0(SerializerBase.java:64)     at Unknown.$serialize(SerializerBase.java:123)     at Unknown.$writeObject(AbstractSerializationStreamWriter.java:126) What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Using guava-gwt-10.0.1 on Ubuntu 10.04 Please provide any additional information below. The likely cause of this is that HashBasedTable calls 'super(backingMap, factory)' when created where its super class (StandardTable) has final instance variables which breaks the contract required by GWT-RPC: "1. A user-defined class is serializable if all of the following apply: It is assignable to IsSerializable or Serializable, either because it directly implements one of these interfaces or because it derives from a superclass that does 2. All non-final, non-transient instance fields are themselves serializable, and 3. As of GWT 1.5, it must have a default (zero argument) constructor (with any access modifier) or no constructor at all."

title: Could ImmutableMap.put() and other such methods be marked @Deprecated?
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=781) created by **bartvanheukelom** on 2011-11-03 at 08:01 PM_

---

If ImmutableMap.put() and methods like it (collection-interface-inherited methods that would modify the collection but in the immutable version just throw an exception) were to be marked @Deprecated, a warning would be issues when this method is called on an object that is known to be immutable at compile time, e.g. 

ImmutableMap map = ...;
map.put(bla, blo); // Warning

Map map = ImmutableMap.copyOf(...);
map.put(bla, blo); // No warning

Maybe this feels strange because @Deprecated would imply that the method could be removed in the future, which it can't without breaking the inheritance, but I feel the advantage of the compile-time warning outweighs that.

title: RemovalListeners semantics bug
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=778) created by **nto...@maginatics.com** on 2011-11-02 at 06:17 PM_

---

I was looking at the RemovalListeners.asynchronous() method and the Javadoc promises that it "processes all eviction notifications asynchronously." However, the implementation in 10.0.1 calls executor.execute() whose Javadoc [1] mentions that "The command may execute... in the calling thread."

If I am reading this correctly, this would make the eviction notification synchronous. Should RemovalListeners.asynchronous() be using an ExecutorService and calling the .submit() method instead?

[1] http://download.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/Executor.html#execute%28java.lang.Runnable%29

title: Enums.values() method.
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=777) created by **ray.j.greenwell** on 2011-10-31 at 07:51 PM_

---

Just a small suggestion:

Add a method to Enums:

public static <E extends Enum<E>> ImmutableList<E> values (Class<E> clazz);

The method maintains a static weak-key Cache mapping the enum Class to an ImmutableList of the values.

This can be used instead of the inefficient Enum.values() that returns a newly allocated array every time. Arrays suck, mutability sucks, and inefficiency sucks too.

The only wrinkle is that 'base' never imports from 'collect'...

body: _[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=776) created by **pondruska+o...@csas.cz** on 2011-10-28 at 09:22 PM_ --- What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Add guava-10.0.1.jar, guava-gwt-10.0.1.jar to build path 2. Compile GWT module What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Compiling module ***    Validating newly compiled units       [ERROR] Errors in 'jar:file:/***/guava/guava-gwt-10.0.1.jar!/com/google/common/base/CharMatcher.java'          [ERROR] Line 29: The import javax.annotation.CheckReturnValue cannot be resolved          [ERROR] Line 871: CheckReturnValue cannot be resolved to a type          [ERROR] Line 908: CheckReturnValue cannot be resolved to a type Also complains not being able to find javax.annotation.Nullable What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? guava 10.0.1, gwt 2.4.0, java se 1.6 Please provide any additional information below. title: Avoid unnecessary computations in the Math API
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=772) created by **ogregoire** on 2011-10-25 at 03:22 PM_

---

I'm already checking the new API for Math as it has very promising stuff for BigIntegers.

However I was surprised that some expensive computation is performed before a NullPointerException is thrown when RoundingMode is null. Can a preemptive check be performed on RoundingMode before it goes in deep computation and the "switch"-statement finally discovers that RoundingMode is null?

title: Iterables.transform() with condition (Predicate)
Clarification of Beta-APIs
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=770) created by **drothmaler** on 2011-10-21 at 09:00 AM_

---

Recently the usage of some API-parts, marked as @Beta caused some misunderstandings inside our team.
Because "beta" sounds evil and buggy.

So it would be nice, if you could include the statement, made at the discussion-group ( http://groups.google.com/group/guava-discuss/browse_thread/thread/16822b864d52608e/4f15baa530a717e9 ) as part of the JavaDoc of the Beta annotation.

Also you may consider renaming the Beta annotation to something more friendly like "SubjectToChange" or "MayChange".

Best regards,
Daniel

title: Provide custom exception handling in EventBus
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=766) created by **toellrich** on 2011-10-20 at 12:05 PM_

---

I would love to replace our implementation of a synchronous event bus with the one from Guava. They do pretty much the same thing except for one notable difference: Ours propagates exceptions that happen during event handling since event handling must occur in the same database transaction as the code that raised the event. Is there any chance to make this configurable (flag/subclassing)?

Cheers
Thomas

title: Function interface mismatch causes failure at runtime
body: _[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=765) created by **Todd.Schiller** on 2011-10-19 at 05:43 AM_ --- I define a Function of the form: new Function<MyType, String>(){   @Override   public String apply(MyType arg0){      return ...;   } } , which compiles in Eclipse as expected. However, at runtime in hosted mode, I receive the following errors: [ERROR] [MyProject] - Line XXX: The type new Function<MyType,String>(){} must implement the inherited abstract method Function<MyType,String>.apply(Object) [ERROR] [MyProject] - Line YYY: The method apply(MyType) of type new Function<MyType,String>(){} must override or implement a supertype method What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Guava GWT 10.0.1 Please provide any additional information below. GWT 2.4.0 Guava 10.0.1 Eclipse 3.7.1 JavaSE-1.6 Fedora Core 14 (2.6.35.14-96.fc14.i686.PAE)

title: request for clone()
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=762) created by **kpietrza...@rajant.com** on 2011-10-17 at 12:03 PM_

---

I would love to see:
 \* the Immutable(Set|Map|etc.) classes implement Cloneable
 \* ...and implement clone()

I don't see any downsides right now, but I'm sure I'm missing something.

If the powers that be don't say no, I'll submit a patch.

P.S. The primary motivator for this is Eclipselink: it uses clone() deep inside its own codebase, so currently I avoid using Guava with my entities, which is a darn shame.

title: Request to revert change to mark ListenableFutureTask as final
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=760) created by **jdsullivan** on 2011-10-16 at 05:34 PM_

---

This is a request that the change to mark ListenableFutureTask as final be reverted. This reduces the utility of this class as applications can no longer override done() to be notified when the task is finished executing. For people familiar with FutureTask, this is an inconsistency in how the class can be used.

If this change can't be made, I'd like to request that a new interface such as RunnableListenableFuture be introduced. This should be similar to RunnableFuture, but implement ListenableFuture as well. The comments for ListenableFutureTask should also be cleaned up to remove references to overriding done().

title: ByteStreams Javadoc inconsistency

labels.name: type=documentation
labels.description: Documentation that is other than for an API

body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=757) created by **paulblessing** on 2011-10-13 at 10:31 PM_

---

https://google.github.io/guava/releases/v10.0.1/apidocs/com/google/common/io/ByteStreams.html#copy(java.io.InputStream, com.google.common.io.OutputSupplier)

The Javadoc for ByteStreams#copy(InputStream, OutputSupplier) reads as follows.

"Opens an output stream from the supplier, copies all bytes from the input to the output, and closes the output stream. Does not close or flush the output stream."

So it closes the output stream, but does not close the output stream? :)

---

I can't find any way to get a locked, unmodifiable, or immutable table.  None of the above.  Can we get some of these?

title: Something about the new eventbus
Maps.computeIfAbsent(Map, K, Supplier)
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=754) created by **finnw1** on 2011-10-13 at 02:01 AM_

---

This is yet another recurring pattern that appears in many programs (sometimes the map can be replaced with a Cache, but not always.)

The full signatures would be something like:

<K, V>V computeIfAbsent(ConcurrentMap<K, V> map, K key, Supplier<V> supp);
and
<K, V>V computeIfAbsent(ConcurrentMap<K, V> map, K key, Function<K, V> func);

Both @NonNull, since unlike ConcurrentMap.putIfAbsent they would return the new value (always present) rather than the old.

title: Document changes between 10.0 and 10.0.1
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=751) created by **j...@nwsnet.de** on 2011-10-11 at 09:49 AM_

---

I found it most appropriate to open this ticket.

The release page (Release10) heralds the release of version 10.0.1. However, I can't find information on the differences, be it:
- details on the ReleaseHistory page
- a milestone I can filter issues for
- a CHANGELOG file

Since the release is already available on Maven Central, now is the time for details on the differences and why one might want to/have to upgrade to be available. Please fix this opaqueness.

title: Make Ints.min() with no arguments not compile (etc.)
Reflection-based newInstanceSupplier()
Consider adding a simple state machine logic
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=748) created by **joern.barthel** on 2011-10-10 at 11:47 AM_

---

Sth. like https://gist.github.com/1275110 could be a useful addition in Guava. A few things that should be improved:
- Separate construction / usage with a builder pattern.
- Don't abuse Cache (comptingMap is deprecated in 10.0 - where is the alternative?)
- Allow for an associated state model (effectively allowing Predicate instances as guards - much more useful).

title: Provide Optionals
Provide Hamcrest / JUnit matchers for Optional
Itera*s methods with "T defaultValue" are missing a wildcard on the input Itera*
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=745) created by **cheremin** on 2011-10-07 at 02:26 PM_

---

Currently signature is

public static <T> T getFirst(Iterable<T> iterable, @Nullable T defaultValue)

but it'll be more usefull to have

public static <T> T getFirst(Iterable<? extends T> iterable, @Nullable T defaultValue)

Same for 

Iterators.getNext(Iterator<T> iterator, @Nullable T defaultValue) 

to become

Iterators.getNext(Iterator<? extends T> iterator, @Nullable T defaultValue)

title: Please don't remove MapMaker.maximumSize
Version of firstNonNull that does not throw a NPE if second is null - firstIfNotNull
Supplier version of firstNonNull
body:
_[Original issue](https://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/issues/detail?id=741) created by **dancerjohn** on 2011-10-06 at 06:21 PM_

---

There are times when firstNonNull is called but where it would be helpful if the second argument was not evaluated unless the first was actually null. I found this to be the case when reading a file and I only wanted the line read if the first was null.

I propose a version of firstNonNull that takes a Supplier as the second argument.

static <T> T firstNonNull(@Nullable T first, @Nonnull Supplier<T> second);

at the moment if primitive fields are logged in ToStringHelper, it autoboxes them. is it worth creating overloaded primitive methods to avoid this?

title: Bit manipulation for primitive types
